p: On the basis of these results, it can be concluded that strains of Gram-positive bacteria were more sensitive to the preparations of R. rosea than Gram-negative bacteria. The reference strains showed greater sensitivity to the test preparations than the clinical strains belonging to the same species ( S. aureus, Salmonella enterica, and E. coli). The MBC values of the preparations were, in most cases, greater than the MIC values. The antibacterial activity of R. rosea preparations has been the subject of very few studies [ 38, 39, 40]. Ming et al. [ 39] showed that the methanol extract of the underground part of R. rosea has inhibitory activity against Staphylococcus aureus. The effect of feeding mice with R. rosea extracts was studied on Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection by Bany et al. [ 41]. The infection intensity was significantly lower in mice after treatment for 7 days with a daily dose of 0.4 mg of aqueous extract than in the control group.
